author: discovercamp110

description.text:
Winged heart sculpture with two different stands.

Printing:

Try to print all objects upright, if possible. This is quite easy with the stands and the heart itself, but you may need a brim and good adhesion for the wings. If you can't manage to print the wings upright, try printing them horizontally. However vertical printing results in the best texture and surface structure here.

There are two wing files included - one to be printed in upright (vertically) and another one if you prefer to print them lying on the build plate. The lying ones require less adhesion. Use whatever you prefer.

There are no supports required for the stands and the heart, but they are recommended for the wings.

You can print all parts from 100% scale up to 200% scale.

author: discovercamp110

title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Model Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
****Many of you asked, so here it is, the Strongback is now available here! https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779030

****The Falcon Heavy Expansion Kit is now available here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2478927

***V2 of the landing leg has now been uploaded. It has been redesigned for easier and more consistent printing.

This is a detailed model of the SpaceX Falcon 9 Rocket. It includes the following:

  1. First stage with landing legs that lock into place.
  2. Grid finds that fold and rotate.
  3. Detachable interstage.
  4. Detachable second stage with an attachment point for your own satellites!
  5. Interchangeable payload. Attach either the payload fairings or dragon cargo capsule to the top of the second stage.
  6. Dragon cargo capsule with detachable trunk, side panels, solar panels, and nose cone cover.

Assembly (See pictures for clarification of part placement):

  1. Glue all four components of the first stage together. There are posts and slots on each piece as a guide. Piece 1 goes on the bottom and 4 on the top.
  2. Attach 4 landing leg struts to part 1 of the first stage. The hooks will snap onto the cylinders that are in each of the four cutouts on the first stage.
  3. Attach first stage engines to the bottom of the first stage. They will snap in place but you can also add some glue.
  4. Attach 4 landing legs to the first stage engines using the landing leg axles. Add a small amount of glue to the end of each axle to glue it to the landing leg.
  5. Attach 4 grid fins to 4 grid fin connectors using the grid fin axles. Add a small amount of glue to the end of each axle to glue it to the grid fin connector. These connectors snap into place on part 4 of the first stage. There are four small holes at the top of this piece for the grid fins.
  6. Glue parts 1 and 2 of the second stage together. Make sure that the ridge on the sides of each piece is aligned.
  7. Glue the second stage engine onto the bottom of second stage part 2. The post will fit into the hole on the bottom of the stage.
  8. All other pieces are detachable. The interstage, second stage, payload fairings, and Dragon trunk all attach by inserting the hooks into the previous stage and gently twisting the piece clockwise.

Printing Recommendations:

  1. Print the landing legs and any pieces with the attachment hooks with at least three perimeters to strengthen them.
  2. Use supports for all pieces. Avoid putting supports underneath the twist hook attachment points as they are hard to remove.

comments.text: I'm having a slight OCD moment with the landing legs.  They aren't symmetrical.  The axle holes at the widest parts are visibly different, even on V2.  I tried to modify them on my own in Fusion (split, mirror, combine) but the landing legs are different in the files you sent me earlier and figuring out the strut lengths etc. is making my brain hurt!  The rest of the model has been great to print.  I ended up splitting a few pieces like the cargo capsule and the trunk.  It gave me a nice clean printed surface with no need for supports.  I do mind a little extra gluing!
comments.author: dpmakestuff

comments.text: They are slightly asymmetrical due to how the software processed the fillets, but should not be significantly different. Can you send a picture of what you mean?
comments.author: dpmakestuff

comments.text: I played around with Fusion a little more and got it figured.  I haven't tested it yet but will tonight.  I also modified the little nubs to hopefully eliminate the need for support on them.  Fingers crossed!

comments.text: I recommend printing the part with the engines facing up. The only supports you need are under the main body of the part. You don't need supports on the engines. You can also increase infill or use more perimeters to strengthen the engines.

comments.text: I am currently trying to print the legs, which seem to be the most difficult part to print. I have read below where it has been said to try printing vertically with the small end down. Yet, when I generate support in slic3r, I still have difficulty supporting the hinge, which is simply floating in the air due to the fact that I am trying not to get support in/around that area.

comments.text: While printing vertically, with the small end down, you should put supports underneath the hinge. The only place really to avoid them is inside the hinge mechanism. The axle will be able to print in mid-air due to the short bridging distance.

comments.text: I'm currently printing this rocket scaled down by 50% in Cura but some parts are altered in the slicing process like the grid fin parts do you have any advice?
comments.author: AseTyr

comments.text: I've printed the whole model too as scaled.  I would think the engines as modeled wouldn't work at all at 50% either.  The nozzles will just fall off.  The hooking mechanism for the interstage, second stage, and fairing will probably not be strong enough as modeled either.  Certainly the legs might have severe problems too.
comments.author: AseTyr

comments.text: The problem is probably that at 50% scale, some of the walls are getting to thin to print. One thing that could help is making sure single walled extrusions are enabled in your slicer. Additionally, you can sometimes get away with telling your slicer you are using a smaller diameter nozzle, which allows some smaller features to be printed. For example, if you have a 0.4mm nozzle, you can enter 0.3mm instead.
comments.author: AseTyr

comments.text: Not working too bad :/ I will try to print the big parts first I will see after that

comments.text: Those wider clearances are on purpose to make sure that they can rotate freely. If you add some glue to the ends of those axles, it will fill the gaps and bond well to the landing legs or grid fin connector but still be able to rotate.

comments.text: This is my print + paint job. Thanks chemteacher628 for a great model.
comments.author: b1033588

comments.text: How did you paint the bottom of the rocket to look like it reentered the atmosphere? It looks incredible!
comments.author: b1033588

comments.text:
airbrushes are amazing. 2 parts tamiya smoke + 1 part tamiya black + 0.5 part tamiya thinner. start with the spray nozzle close to the engines, then rapidly move up the 1st stage shaft while moving the nozzle away from the model roughly the same distance.
This will give you a nice uniform burn pattern. But fire isn't uniform, so i went over the model and made a few darker spots at random.
i tested this first on a white sheet of paper. looked good so i applied to the model.
its easy to overdo. please exercise restraint with effects.
comments.author: BCufr

comments.text: That paint job looks great!
comments.author: b1033588

comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: Really nice model! In various parts of the model there are holes to "hook" parts in (interstage, first stage 1, first stage 4, second stage 1). I have quite some issues to remove support from "under" the axle in those holed where parts hook behind. How did you accomplish this? Did you print without supports?
comments.author: Highfield

comments.text: Thanks! I had the same problem when I was first printing the model. You do not need to use supports under the axle when printing. In my slicer, I used automatic supports and then removed the supports manually from around the axle before slicing.
comments.author: Highfield

comments.text: I presume you use Simplify3D as your slicer? I've been unable to get the desired supports in either Cura or Sli3er..
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: That is correct, but all you need is software that lets you use manual supports. Flashprint is another option that I know has this feature.
comments.author: Highfield

comments.text: Hi. I love this model and I am in the process of making a F9 now. I am also going to make the FH model soon. You mentioned the attachment point for "Your own satellites." I was wondering If you could design some of the satellites that were recently launched like Iridium-3 and Echostar 101. If you can't design them, could I have the exact diameter of the hole for the attachment point?
comments.author: enderjack

comments.text: I was just thinking the same thing watching the recent launches! It is not something that I will be able to get to any time soon, but I would love to see what you can come up with. The diameter of the hole on the second stage is 10.1 mm. The diameter of the fairing is about 48 mm.
comments.author: enderjack

comments.text: What orientation did you print the landing legs in? I'm having difficulty removing supports and keeping the strut from breaking.
comments.author: phdrumlineka

comments.text: I have the best results with I print the legs vertically with the small end down. This requires more support, but allows the hinge to print easily. Also, make sure that no supports are present within the hinge itself, and print slowly.
comments.author: phdrumlineka

comments.text: I have been having problems printing the strut (the part with the hook). any ideas?
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: I recommend printing the struts horizontally with the hook opening upwards. I would also use supports, 0.3mm layer height and turn off the cooling fan if you have one. It is such a small part that you want to make sure that the layers fuse together well.
comments.author: enderjack

comments.text: thanks for reply. trying it tonight
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: Thank you for the reply, I will give that a try.
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: I am glad you enjoy the model! I like your strong back idea. It is not something that I will be able to get to for a little while, but I will put it on my list for future models to build. Thanks for the suggestion.

comments.author: A_Man11

comments.text: hey, I have been wanting to print a nice Flacon9 for a long time. I love your attention to detail and they way everything is moveable.
comments.author: Vipitis

comments.text: Thanks! How much filament you use will depend on your printer and print settings. For the entire model, I probably used about .75kg of white filament printing an average of .2mm layer height with 2 perimeters and 3 bottom and top layers (although that includes some misprints). You will need significantly less of the other colors.
comments.author: Vipitis

comments.text: Having issues when slicing the grid fin in Simplify 3d. Once sliced the grid itself is incomplete with holes?
comments.author: DarrenG

comments.text: I ran into the same issue where the grid fin after slicing had missing "grids". I tried Simplify 3D, Slic3r, and Cura, all with the same result. I ended up correcting the stl on MakePrintable and the corrected version sliced fine. I am attaching the corrected stl. See if it helps you.
comments.author: DarrenG

comments.text: Printed perfectly, thank you.
comments.author: le_avion

comments.text: Awesome, I will give it a whirl and report back - thank you!
comments.author: le_avion

comments.text: Hi DarrenG,
comments.author: DarrenG

comments.text: What is your nozzle diameter? The features on the grid fin are very small. I printed on a 0.4mm nozzle (slicing also with Simplify3D) and that worked well. The other setting you might need to check is whether or not you have single walls enabled.
comments.author: DarrenG

comments.text: Thanks for the reply, Flashforge Creator Pro with a 0.4mm nozzle. I've just enabled single walls so will test again. And thanks for this model!
comments.author: chemteacher628

comments.text: Just a silly question, do you mean the holes in the grid fin? the grid fin is a grid of holes, for the air to pass through.. like a giant waffle, but with each square cut straight through
comments.author: DarrenG

title: Piper J-3 Cub Balsa Kit Parts

description.text: I recently built the Alien Aircraft Piper J-3 Cub balsa kit. I have had no luck with Japanese Cub kits. Never flew very well. This one is much better. Only problems are the very weak, light-weight battery door latch and landing gear that have no chance of surviving a hard landing. I designed a new battery door and beefed up the landing gear mount. The dummy motor is from mf19811 (Piper J3 Motor). I haven't bothered to glue the landing gear mount in. It fits tight.

comments.author: djbezinque

description.text:
I hate TVs... they take up a lot of space and are always a pain to move. I've had to move locations about 8 times in the last year-and-a-quarter so traveling light is a priority. To remedy having to lug a large TV box with me everywhere I go, I got a small projector.

Problem is, if I want to avoid losing my deposit, drilling a hole in the ceiling is not an option. Still, I like to mount my projector above me but it has to be upside down to render the image properly. So, I bought a simple drying rack from Lowe's, cut out some of the sides and used it as a cage from which to hang the projector.

One final step, so that I can easily level the image on the projected wall, is to create these adjusters that simply slide onto the cage. Clever, eh?

If you found this useful, it would bring me great joy to see your work - so be sure to share. :)

Or, better yet, please feel free to dump a bitcoin or two here:

1Py3TUeR8noBN2giHyFV1GfB6x3Kh2WEVv

... include a note to the effect of "Hi 3E8, thanks for the iPhone 7 cover thing... my life is infinitely better on account of it and please accept this paltry amount in gratitude".

You're welcome! (in advance) :D

Also, feel free to peruse my other submissions which are almost as varied as they are many:

http://www.thingiverse.com/3E8/designs

Enjoy!

remixed_from.author: dkennell
remixed_from.title: Pocket Printer Upgrade - hybrid roller slides

description.text:
The K1-Rap is a derivative of Dkennel's Pocket Printer. I loved the design and idea of the Pocket Printer but was unable to get the "slides" working correctly. Since I had 8mm smooth rods and lm8uu bearings on my Prusa, I decided to cannibalize it and start a new design based on the Pocket Printers basic shape. Check out: www.entropyprojects.blogspot.com for the full details. I'll update this as I change things. Edit:
Due to popular demand, I changed the name to include the build number. Hopefully this clears things up.

Full instructions and BOM to come once I stop making changes. STL's are in the Zip Folder. You'll also need the pocket printer's xymotor mount, RAMPS holder (if needed), and Prusa's lm8uu Y bearing holder. Parts needed: 2 - Zmount
6 - barendbracket
1- Zslide 2L
1- Zslide 2R
1- xmotor
1- xidler
1- yendbracket
1-yendbracket2
2-ySlide
1-hotendmount (this may not work for everyone, if you need a different hole spacing let me know)
1-beltbracket
3-endstop Vitamins:
Aluminum Extrusions:
Z Cantilever = 180mm 2060
Z Vertical = 300mm 2060
Y = 425mm 2060 (Mine currently is shorter than this because I miscalculated. This is what it should be at least. A little more wouldn't hurt anything)
X = 2x 350mm 2020
"Legs" = 1x 350mm 2020 and 1x 150mm 2020 Smooth Bars:
Same sizes as axes, 2 per axis.
11 or 12 lm8uu linear bearings 2x 220mm threaded rod. I use 5/16 since I'm in the US, but 8mm will work too.
Plus whatever Z couplers you prefer. 3 Nema 17 steppers
1 Nema 14 stepper (X axis)
Belts/pulleys/idlers are your personal preference. (I use T5, right off of my Prusa)

comments.text: Fabulous design, I might retire my non working Prusa (Polulus blown up) and make this instead with the parts, I might then make another Prusa.
comments.author: ipblythe

comments.text: I put the Z motors up top because it was just easier to get them out of the way.  The Y motor is mounted right next to the vertical Z axis so it would be in the way of the second Z.  With that in mind, this design doesnt need 2 Z motors.  I only include them because I plan on adding a second extruder to it and I wanted to keep the Z speeds high.  If interested, I can put together a quick single Z version.  Then you can mount the Z on the bottom.
comments.author: ipblythe

title: Cub Scouts Neckerchief Slide "Blue and Gold" dual extrusion

description.text:
I made this Cub Scouts neckerchief slide for our "Blue and Gold" activity this month for my cub scout pack. Our theme is "Invention Convention" so as the Cubmaster, I wanted to show them something I invented.  
This looks best in blue and gold/yellow for cub scouts. The wording can be modified, but you're on your own for that. I put our pack number on mine and plan to give them to boys this week.  
STL files are included for both colors and a MakerBot THING file that already has them in the same file for direct printing. And, of course, this requires the dual extruder to work. You need BOTH the YELLOW and the BLUE pieces to get the complete print.  
The slide is made from two pieces and the ring snaps into place in the back of the badge, but you should put a bit of superglue in there to make it stays. Don't press it in too hard or you'll flex the front background plastic. It should take a minor bit of force to get it into place, but you don't have to cram it hard.  
I made this in two pieces after my prototype in one piece didn't make a smooth ring on the back. I broke it apart so the ring builds vertically around the circle instead with the top as an arch, which sometimes distorted the ring.  
I also used glow-in-the-dark yellow filament for this neckerchief slide, because kids love that sort of thing! See the dark photo. You can even read the words in pitch black!  
Enjoy it and let me know what you think!  
(I may add additional versions that replace Cub Scouts with Tiger, Bobcat, Bear, and Wolf.)

I wanted to print something for my wife for valentines day. I liked the rose petals from XYZWorkshop (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:152642), but wanted a better stem than a 3mm filament. I designed two different stems, one with and one without thorns. The attached oscad script lets you select number of thorns and angle, then evenly spaces them vertically and radially around the stem. Note: The rose petal STL is from thing 152642 (see above). I.e. not my design.

Printed at standard setting in makerware on a Replicator 2. Note, thorn angle likely has to be >=45 to avoid overhang problems, but YMMV depending on the printer.  
I used a drop of superglue to connect the stem and flower.

comments.text: Tweaked the length of the stem with thorns to 185mm in length. And printed it Vertical on my Delta. Amazingly it printed. Great project.

This is a thing made for relieving the Z rods from the tension of the X belt, when the X gantry would otherwise collapse and bend the Z rods.
Put an M3 nut in each of the small slots and M3 screws through them, as shown in the video.

By now I know about the threaded holes on the back of the block holding the rods. It's been pointed out that they would achieve the same goal, but they do not as this lets you adjust the gantry's width, not just fixating it.

I'm not telling you to print this though. It's just a thing I made that does what I wanted it to.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3dtkFm_HmNI

The FCStd file is the cad file for FreeCad:
https://www.freecadweb.org/

title: ABS print coated with molten metal!

description.text: This is an ABS print of a beautiful girl's face. As an experiment I had California Metal Spray (http://californiametalspray.com) arc spray it with molten zinc. The process involves a machine like a MIG welder with two zinc wires which arc off of each other and the resulting cloud of molten metal droplets is deposited on the workpiece by an air jet. This process is commonly done on metal, but it imparts so little heat that it is possible for a skilled operator to coat many different materials including, it turns out, ABS prints. Arc spray is capable of delivering many metals including bronze, stainless and carbides. It might be possible to spray a thick enough layer of metal that the abs print could be melted away leaving just a metal shell.

comments.text:
Guys,
I have been doing it in my own company in a robotic CNC setup, check this out;
http://www.metcom.co/news/metallizing-is-seductivehttp://www.metcom.co/news/meta...
Best, arda
comments.author: samiaruda

comments.text: I was having them arc spray a steel piece for a job and I though it would be cool to see if they could do ABS.  The operator who did the spray said the ABS started to yellow a bit, but then the metal started to build and it worked fine.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text: Yes, I've made about 5 face casts this way. I've just uploaded the process here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:247363http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text:
Never even thought of arc spraying. That's very interesting, it looks like it didn't hurt the ABS.
Is your goal to cast it into a metal? If you vacuum form the face then set a mold from it with plaster of paris you can create a positive and negative mold. Next, drop the positive into the negative while you've got molten metal in the negative and you'll have a hollow model with a thin layer of metal.
comments.author: lordkylo

comments.text: DIY arc spray rig is probably possible, but I don't know anyone doing it.  Electroforming is a lot easier.  I'll have to try it.
comments.author: Shapespeare

comments.text:
Thanks for posting this!
I would suggest that using ABS acetone could be used as a solvent to remove the plastic.
Using the soluble filaments (makerbot has one http://store.makerbot.com/dissolvable-filament)http://store.makerbot.com/diss...
the same could be done.
Also, this would be a good starting point for electroforming. a metal shell that could be plated.
but I had considered the spraying as a option, but I do not have the equipment currently.
I suspect a electro-welder and a compressor could be used to make a DIY version (i suspect
spraying hot zinc in a diy set-up would be a recipe for pain!).
but thanks again, I am always looking for ways to leverage FDM to metal.
comments.author: cerberus333

description.text:
I wanted a Navy emblem to put on my motorcycle and I looked for challenge coins but then I thought I might be unhappy if it falls off so with a 3d printed part, I can just print another one.
Have not tried it yet but I hope to print one this weekend.
I based this on a regular challenge coin but I plan on sizing it up a bit to make it fit.
side note, the reason for this is my bike had two round emblems on the trunk when I bought it but they were masons symbols and when they finally fell off you can see it in the paint so I thought if I get something to cover it it would look better. so here we are
Thin version

Fish on the line!
I Printed in ABS but I'm sure PLA would work fine too. Can be printed with supports on or off.
The fish has a through hole and a counterbored hole to hide the knot.
Easy for kids to use and nice and light so it wont put any strain on the switch.

remixed_from.author: ArtInstituteChicago
remixed_from.title: Iconic Lion at the Steps of the Art Institute of Chicago

title: Iconic Lion at the Steps of the Art Institute of Chicago (south)

description.text:
I am honored to be Artist-In-Residence at the Art Institute of Chicago. Between now and the end of June 2014 i'll be working on a new body of work in the Ryan Education Center; and giving demonstrations in 3D printing, scanning and modeling. To celebrate the start of the residency I decided to scan and publish the second Lion by Edward Kemeys that guards the front steps to AIC on Michigan Avenue. In the summer of 2012 i scanned and published the north Lion and have since used this scan in many of my 3D printed art works. Today I am uploading the second Lion - who guards the south end of the entrance - i'll be working on making a number of pieces with both of the Lions over the next couple of months and integrating them into the demonstrations and workshops. Edward Kemeys
American, 1843-1907 Lions (a pair), 1893 Bronze with green patina
261.7 x 114.2 x 287 cm (103 x 45 x 113 in.) Gift of Mrs. Henry Field, 1893.1a-b ® The Art Institute of Chicago
American Art
Michigan Avenue entrance/steps http://www.artic.edu/aic/collections/artwork/656?search_no=1&index=0 http://www.artic.edu/event/artist-residence-3-d-printing-tom-burtonwood

These are parts for the Hyperlite Floss. The parts for standoffs have a "cap" to them that is 2mm. This raises the top plate a little and provides some cushion in a crash.

I HIGHLY recommend using a washer for the top camera mount screws. which should be m2x4. It's designed for the runcam mini. If you use m2x6 or larger you may damage your camera board. This has nothing to do with my design just use caution and common sense.

The shark fin is to hang antennas to protect them.

The wire covers are sized to BARELY fit 2204 motor wires. If you have 18g 2206 wires or larger you may have to stretch the design.

I printed on a prusa mk2s with sainsmart TPU. 20-40% infill honeycomb works great.

A clip-on side panel for peon230

Made so that you don't have to worry about a wire getting out or dirt getting it.

I made 3 sizes, 30,35 and 40 mm tall depending on the standoffs you use.

It's made for standoffs with 5mm outer diameter, it clips on them easily and when you crash hard, the side panel will sometimes eject. Which is good, because you can just clip it back on and it would break, if it stayed. It's made really thin, so it weighs close to nothing.

I only uploaded one side of the model, use mirror function in your favourite slicer to create the other side.

I like to print mine with PETG, you can even play with translucent materials and add some led lights to the inside.

title: LED Indicating Fuse Box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a simple fusebox with LEDs that will show you instantly when a fuse blows. If an LED is lit, the fuse is good!

Quick note about the picture: I only had one bolt partially in when I took the picture. It accepts bolts on all four corners with no problems :)

I got frustrated with the poly-fuses often used on 3D printer boards. They are typically undersized and extremely unreliable, blowing even when you are below their rating. Instead, I wanted a fused solution with easy-to-find automotive fuses.

The face plate holds the fuses and can be attached to the enclosure with almost any-length M3 bolts. The enclosure is deep enough to allow you to use crimp-on spade connectors without trouble. If you find the enclosure is too deep for you, simply scale it on the "Z" axis - the screw holes go all the way through almost to the back.

For schematics, list of materials (BOM), and build instructions, see my blog post here:
http://www.foxrobotics.com/2017/07/22/make-an-indicating-fuse-box/

IMPORTANT: I purposefully did not include mounting holes on the enclosure. I personally hate it when folks include mounting holes as they very rarely line up with everything and I end up with either ugly holes or have to take a chunk of time to remove them from a model before printing. It is far easier to drill holes (or add them to a model) than they are to remove.

You can easily add holes to the model for your purposes in programs like 123D or online services like TinkerCAD.com. Likewise, you can pick up a drill online or from places like Harbor Freight or $20.

I personally love 3M's double-sided, permanent adhesive tape for small things like this. I actually used exactly that to mount the box on my 3D printer to great affect.

Printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2X in white ABS. The levers are in two versions - normal and with pads to improve adhesion to the build platform. (The pads can easily be removed after print)  
For the pin for the levers, I used a 1.8mm piano rod cut to 11 mm. Any kind of rod in of diameter 1.5-2mm should work.   
Lightening cables can be inserted from the bottom through a slot on the side. They will probably stay in place without, but I choose to hot-glue them in place.

comments.text: Are you using the original Apple Lightening cables? I experienced that copies from other manufacturers, often needed more force to eject. The levers are better printed in PLA, if printed with ABS they probably need high fill-rate 35-50% to get the necessary stiffness. As for the wiggling, what kind of rod/pin do you use?  I found a stainless 1.8-2mm rod (i.e. piano string) to work best. If you want more separation between left and right levers, you can hot glue in a piece of rod between the levers on the inside of the lever opening. However, be careful to do this as a last step after you have everything in place.

author: nbstuart

description.text:
This was a 3rd grade "Invention Convention" project. The goal was to make a low-cost durable rock tumbler using 3D printed parts.  
There are a number of parts included here and some additional materials required (motor, drive belt, plywood, machine screws and nuts, power supply, PVC pipe, 5/16-inch square steel, etc).  
Use this to print parts which can be used to put something like this together. The original design used a small DC geared motor which was too weak, and we switched to using a variable-speed drill motor (14.4V) with a rotary actuator for the speed control. Otherwise the amount of starting current is too great for a basic power supply.  
See assembly instructions for details on materials used.

In addition to the planetary gear end bearings, we used inexpensive 5/16-inch square steel rod for the drive shaft (about USD $3.17 for a 10 food length at my local metal supply).  
We ended up taking apart an old variable-speed reversible drill and putting a drive pully in the chuck, and mounting the speed control to the inside of the box with a nautilus-shaped actuator.  
The rollers were 2 inch PVC with the spacer parts inside. The fit was tight enough that no ABS glue was needed.  
Everything went inside a box made of plywood. We used machine screws to hold the ends on so it could easily be taken apart for repairs and/or upgrades.  
The timing belt was a 13" timing belt purchased on Amazon. In retrospect a longer one would have been much better.  
The motor clamps were used to provide tension on the pulley.

comments.text: How much longer of a belt should be used?
comments.author: Hathalud

comments.text:
Hard to say - the 13 inches is circumference, I probably would have been better off using something more like 18 inches. Since the mountings are screwed to the box, it wouldn't change any of the parts. The roller spacing turned out to be just right for even a larger jar, with a longer drive belt the motor mount could be a bit lower.
I also ended up having to replace the original integrated shaft pulley design with a metal shaft - the ABS shaft would break after running for only 24 hours or so.
comments.author: Hathalud

description.text: Working on port holes for the Lilka model

I use this with my 1806 brushless motors. The primary method of bonding is glue, but there is a hole for a wooden bbq skewer for extra support. description.text:
v2 uploaded: slotted one hole - I don't use the original bolts for assemling the frame and didn't realize it blocked that t-nut.

The stock motor mounts flex when the belt is tensioned properly on the Creality Ender-4 h-bot, so I designed and printed these to eliminate that. 4 attachment points on 2 planes.

Prints without supports. I recommend PETG or ABS but a good PLA will probably work.

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

I used 4 perimeters, .35mm layers, 50% infill with Hatchbox PETG.

Installation

You will have to put one of the 2 closest to the angle t-nuts in after attaching with the other 3.
Designed in Fusion 360

title: REBEL Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my own design.. I was bored..
This spinner is made for a 16 mm bearing in diameter. The width of the nuts used is 12.7 mm or 0.5 inches. The whole spinner is about 7.5 cm in diameter.

That 3D visualization is a part of a program that i released a while ago in case you're wondering.. the program is called Multi-Filamentier. It basically inserts the command "M600" to a desired height.
The command M600 pauses the print for a filament change.
Oh and the program also features AutoUpdate :)

So in case you wanted to check that out, here's a link: http://tiny.cc/Multi-Filamentier

REBEL 2

100%

This is the universal lock pinning follower I'm using.
It has on one side a hole that takes and holds pins, which makes repinning easy and on the other side is a big V-groove which works even nicer (I'm using this side usually).
It is made for 12.5mm core diameter.
It also has a slit for a DIY pinning shoe.
I recommend printing the V4 follower (it's the newer version) and print it with the V-groove down, this way it prints nicest.
I also added now a hollow follower (can take a little flashlight like the LedLenser K1L) and one for the Kaba Quattro S locks.

author: damianarenos

title: 10mm 1:150 scale raised road sections - MDF Wargame Terrain
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
03SEP2017 1100EST Added another page of road sections, mostly long straight aways, shorter adaptors and assorted y-intersections 45 y-split, 30, 45 and 60 side roads. Reversing the layers in print or during assembly will double your possibilities (left or right). Meant to be cut at 300DPI for raster resolution, as per all my lasercut file patterns. Otherwise, follow any other advice listed below.

Added 6mm road alignment templates 18AUG2017 2145EST. Sized for 6mm thick MDF on 8.5x11' sheet. More section designs to follow once I start putting pieces together.

Interlocking road sections. Another experiment with custom cut MDF terrain (like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2301897) for my growing collection of 10mm or 1/150 scale armor (http://www.thingiverse.com/search?q=m_bergman&sa=). Produces a few different road straights, bends (30, 45, 60, 90 degs), a t-intersection and terminators. Other sections likely to follow.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C) sheet, the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. Sheet has a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

print_settings.Notes:: I'm printing these with PLA and cooling for precision.

description.text:
This is the body of my lock (re-)pinning shoe for Euro locks.
You just need to add the pinning needle. I make mine from hairclips (Mibella Basic), bent and cut to the right lenth (in an L shape - 20mm x 32mm).
At the back is a hole for a little setscrew, to hold the pinning needle in place. This way you can also adjust the hight and how tight it sits on the lock.
There are also two little side wings on the pinning shoe. You can use them to hold the shoe in place with a short rubber band, but that's usually not needed.

author: BusyBrewing

description.text:
Filament Runout Sensor part for Raise3D N-series printers.

This part is designed to use the N-series endstop to create a sensor to detect when filament has runout.

You will need the following for this.
1 or 2 of this endstop from raise3d depending on how many sensors you want to make
https://www.raise3d.com/collections/accessories/products/copy-of-n-series-spare-parts-hot-end-assembly-v2

for each sensor you need
1x Raise3D endstop
2x M6x7mm 8mm OD Knurled Threaded Insert
2x PC4-M6 Push-In Fittings

Each sensor will also need a cable that needs
2x JST-XHP 2 pin male plugs and matching pins.
2x wires to run from the sensor to the RUMBA board,

wiring and connectors to connect the endstops to the motion controller board.

to note: I listed as no derivatives because changes to the design could lead to it not functioning properly. If you wish to use alternate push-in fittings and threaded inserts, I will make versions for that.

further note: image is of a production model.

There is an arrow indicating filament direction. In that arrow, is a small hole that filament can fit in. This is like a reset button used to make sure the arm is in place when feeding filament into it. Both sides are detachable to make it easier to get the filament inserted.

comments.text: whats the behaviour when the filament runs out? does the printer pause the print?
comments.author: smoki3

comments.text:
software: you need a raisepack install that support the filament runout. You also need one of the firmwares that support it as well.
firmware there are serveral options.
There is the option from raise3d which is based on 1.1.6-rev1 (I dubbed 1.1.6-rev2). This is based on the official marlin 1.0.6 firmware.
there is my 1.1.7 which is 1.1.6-rev2 with the thermal runaway code fixed properly and adds some functionality to control the lack of filament code raise added.
then there is my 1.2.2 firmware which is based on official marlin firmware version 1.1.0.

author: atocha

description.text:
This 3D-printable pyramid puzzle was made in Cinema 4D using the MoGraph Moronoi Fracture feature.

Settings were adjusted to create a 0.3 mm air gap between all individual elements, enabling the whole pyramid to be 3D-printed in place as one single STL file. The Bevel Deformer in Cinema 4D was then used to create a 0.5 mm chamfer to break all the sharp edges.

We provide STL files for a single print-in-place, a flat build plate, and all ten individual parts.

VIDEO
  • https://youtu.be/ppX9A8Hc1Hk
About the Voronoi algorithm
  • https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Voronoi_diagram
About MAXON Cinema 4D
  • http://maxon.net
  • http://creativetools.se/maxon

By Creative Tools

Home - Youtube - Things - #3DBenchy - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Instructables - Instagram - Pinterest - Flickr - LinkedIn - #MadeByCreativeTools

comments.text: This is awesome! So if I were to print this, the layers are far enough apart to be separated? The way I could really describe this is like support; I normally use a .125mm gap in between the interface layers and the part, so I was wondering if .3mm were too large of a tolerance.
comments.author: Matthew813

comments.text: Thanks Matthew for your comment and appreciation. :) The single STL file with all the pyramid parts assembled can be used in most filament-based 3D printers with standard print settings (such as 0.2 mm layer height). All parts touching the build plate will print perfectly. The few top parts will also print nicely but maybe get a bit stuck to the parts underneath. These can be easily be broken off from the rest.
comments.author: Matthew813

comments.text: please let us know when you find out. also what layer height you used ?
comments.author: Matthew813

comments.text: Thanks for asking! :)

title: Wargame Forest Basing Micro Armor 6mm  to 10mm Scale
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Pre-perforated MDF basing for forests for my growing collection of 10mm or 1/150 scale armor (http://www.thingiverse.com/search?q=m_bergman&sa=). Produces a variety of round shaped forests sizes (you don't have to use every perforation). Also includes a few hedge rows.

Palm tree instruction courtesy of http://18charlie.com/

I mount the trees using hot glue, carpenter's or gorilla carpenter's glue and fill remaining holes with medium acrylic gel, which you can also use to add layers of texture to the ground (pictured).

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C) sheet, the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. Sheet has a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

remixed_from.author: DCH78
remixed_from.title: Anycubic I3 Mega Customized Hotend Cover - noise reduction and led strip

title: Anycubic i3 Mega "Noise Reducing" Hotend cover

description.text:
This is a remix of a couple other parts.

The original Hot End Cover did exactly what I needed it to do. It stopped the high pitched noise coming from the right side fan. Seems the air rushing through those little tiny holes acted like a flute.

The led light strip feature didn't actually work very well according to the maker because of the bed leveling censor being in the way so I took it off. Makes it better for seeing the extruder with that gone. Also the original didn't have any grill over the holes. Then I just embedded the grill into the part over the big holes.

Came out fairly well with minimal supports. I didn't have any supports in the grill areas. Printed at .1 mm.

author: element3

title: Anycubic i3 Mega Camera Mouting Braket 2.0 and Adapters

description.text:
2.0 Version UPDATE: I made the top thicker and sturdier and extended it out in front so I could get the camera farther away from the build platform. Also gave it two hole options for mounting the camera mount. Made a few more adapters too for more attachment options.

This is a bracket and set of adapters for setting up a camera for time lapse or monitoring. I tried some of the mounts attached to the bed but it just didn't work so hot for me. Focus on the part was poor and the camera shook quite a bit from the bed moving, often violently. I also tried a little tripod. Didn't fit my small space very well. This set up gives me a very stable way to mount a camera with a small footprint.

I'm using an older smart phone, a Moto G so I needed a way to attache that. I had a universal hot shoe adapter so I made a few parts with a hot shoe slot. A smart phone is really great because you can do time lapse (I use an android app called "Lapsit" and you can use it to monitor a print via wifi with an app like "AtHome" and companion "At Home AVS Streamer". The AtHome app doesn't require an account. Works great for live monitoring.

Also made a Go Pro style adapter and a couple hot shoe adapters for that in case I wanted to be able to move the camera up or down a bit.

I really wanted a mount that didn't require me to take anything apart. This mounts securely using only two existing screw holes.

Mounting the bracket is simple but a little tricky. The two existing screws you need to use are too short and they hold something inside so you have to remove them one at a time to keep the object inside attached. I used an 8mm screw instead of the originals. Remove the top screw first. Set the bracket an angle like in the photo. Insert the longer screw and screw it in a bit so you have a good connection to the part inside. Don't tighten all the way yet. Remove the second original screw next. Then position the bracket in place, snapping in the six pegs in the vent holes on the right side of the printer. Then screw in the second screw and tighten both. That's it.

I also made a support for the adapters to bear the weight of the smart phone or camera that slides into the hot shoe slot. Virtually eliminates any shaking.

About printing this, it will print just fine only needing supports under the six pins that go into the vent holes.

Also, very important to print the screw adapters 100% infill or the screw portion with break right off when you tighten down the nut on it.

author: element3

title: Hictop Ender 2 LCD and Control Mod

description.text:
I wanted to change the viewing angle of the LCD and the controller was on the same board. I angled it all up a bit more so when I'm using my remote camera or operating it, its easier to see. It fits nice and snug. You'll need 4 more nuts and bolts with the original ones to attach it.

9/15/2017 - Adjusted the LCD opening a bit so it covers better and moved the knob hole (lol) down a bit.

12/23/2017 - Looks like this mod is not compatible with the single fan mod. The fan goes too far to the left and hits the housing. As I do not have the fan mod I will not be adjusting. If someone wants the tinkercad files I can look into it.

1/3/2018 Thanks to Fuganater for a solution if you want the LCD mod and fan mod.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2745079

From the Voidscape rules codex (WIP):  
"Driven to explore to stars by an intense curiosity, the Sehlix and the Orthion bonded quickly, forming an ironclad alliance and laying the foundation of an interstellar empire.  
Equally at home in and out of the water, the Sehlix are lithe and athletic creatures. Though rarely known for pioneering new technologies or for their capacity as warriors, their openness and proficiency at inter-species communication has often kept tenuous encounters with newly discovered species from escalating.  
Due to their adventurous spirit, many Sehlix may be found living in Fringe Space. Less concerned with profit, many of these fringers are there solely for the excitement of discovery."

description.text:
I've been having a lot of fun lately using OpenSCAD to tinker with other people's models, usually to make them 2-color. (See my other things for more examples.) ShamusTheTinker's D10/D20 is cool but I found the numbers a bit hard to see, so I remixed it to fill the numbers with a second color to make them stand out better.

NB: My printer is (still) on the fritz so I haven't actually printed this yet, but it's simple enough that it should work fine. I'm still kind of new at this, so any feedback would be appreciated.

description.text:
This is a custom box made for an Orthogone GPS tracker PCB. The device uses NXP Kinetis Processor (ARM Cortex M0+ M4). One one side is a GPS module and LORA long distance radio. On on the other side is another LORA receiving (RX) radio and a BLE radio. This RX side connects to your cellphone. The TX side sends its GPS coordinates Over LORA so you can track or find it within approx 2KM radius. This is completely independent of an network or cellullar connection. if the TX is farther away, as soon as you get within range it will then show up on the RX side. For example if you lost your Drone, or Bicycle, you could drive around until you were approx within 2km range, and then immediately find it.

This is a simple box for these radios. Designed for when they still have their debugging interfaces attached, and the LORA radio and GPS antenna cable just sticks out the slot. The little LiPo battery sits underneath the board.

description.text:
This is an accessory for the Letherman Wave which holds additional bits. With this part, you can bring 4 additional bits with you, making you ready for almost anything!

Note #1: The accessory might fit other Letherman models as well, but I have not tested this.
Note #2: This is the one of the first versions of this object. After I have tested it in day-to-day circumstances, I might update some facets of it.
Note #3: I take no responsibility for any lost or damaged bits!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm Nozzle, 0.25mm Layer Height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The tollerance of the bit holder is 0.6mm. In addition to the semi-friction fit, the bits will be secured by the side of the pocket on the letherman pouch, so they SHOULD not fall out.

Inserting bits

I have not tested all the bits, but they should fit with more or less effort. The arrows on the part shows which way to insert the bits. Simply push one end of the bit in, in the direction of the arrow.

I had to remove some material for one of the bits I am carrying (using the Letherman, of course). However, it was not a major modification!

Assembly and use

The accessory fits the lether pouch that is sold together with the Letherman Wave. Simply insert the part in the pocket of the pouch, and use the loop at the top to secure it. I use an M3 nut & bolt going through both the part's attachment point and the pouch's pocket loop. However, there are probably more convenient methods!

author: 3DMaka

title: Improved Hip & Waist joints for Mad Cat MKII
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: When printing/assmbling the Mad Cat MKII BattleMech (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:44025), I found that the hip and waist joints were far too weak (at least for me) -- the tabs would break off just cleaning up the part (if not while removing it from the print bed), let alone trying to actually use it to connect the Mech's parts.. So, I set out to design stronger joints, and this is what I came up with. These will not break, period! In each case the "snap in" part is replaced by two halves that are inserted first, then a center piece is inserted between the two halves, forcing them to remain "full diameter", retaining them in the groove. In the case of the hip, there should be enough clearance to put the two rotator halves into the engine (one at a time); if not, the flat sides of the halves that face each other can be sanded and/or snip a little more of the lip off where it has already been flattened to increase the clearance enough to fit them in. The insert (that has the pins that connect to the leg) snaps into the two rotator halves, keeping the halves apart and retained in the engine. For the waist, the "bases" were tight enough for a friction fit (no glue); same procedure, put the two halves into the upper joint, then put the insert between them; then press the engine onto it. You may need to sand or scrape the joint or square recess it sits in depending on your print, and how well the support material was removed from the engine.

NOTES:
I printed the original model at 3500%, so the size of these parts is based on that; you will need to scale these appropriately to match the scale you printed the Mad Cat in. After printing the first hip joint, I adjusted things slightly to make the pieces fit together better; since I had to do some sanding on the rotator flat sides (to make more space between them, so they'd fit in the socket), and trim the insert to fit (it was too tight). The second hip I printed still needed some cleanup to get it to fit (I didn't adjust by enough). I also found that the second hip is slightly trickier to fit the insert into because you cannot hold the rotators in position from the backside; but I got it in; very nice results.

Print two of each "half" parts (they're symmetrical).  And one insert.  
Print two sets of the hip parts for two hip joints; they are also symmetrical, so different parts are not necessary.  The rounded-off part of the leg connection should face up (allowing the legs to move further "outward" vs. under the Mech.  
The waist halves are intentionally printed "on their side" so that the sheering force will be perpendicular to the print layers, making it virtually impossible to snap off the "tab".  
To install, first insert the two halves one at a time (you may need to trim off a little bit of the "lip" that fits into the rotation groove in the engine part in order to get the second one inserted.  The idea is that the amount of "gap" provides enough clearance to insert the second one once the first one is slotted in the rotation groove.  Once the two halves are in place, insert the the center part, which forces the halves to remain separated, preventing them from slipping out of the rotation groove.  
The waist joint works on the same pricipal; insert the two halves, then force the center piece in to "lock" the halves into the joint.  
The files named "visual reference" are there to show what the combined part should look like when installed, and are not meant to be printed.

comments.text: Okay, I give up..... what scale did you use?  When I printed the MadCat model, I was converted from inches to mm, but when I opened this model up, it appears to already be in mm.   But, it is also slightly too large.  I have to scale to 3500x, versus 2540x times.  I'm going with 72.5% of your original size.
comments.author: blackt1ger

comments.text: I used no scaling (for my parts).  I printed the original parts as-is (from what I remember... that was a long time ago :), as well as my own.
comments.author: blackt1ger

comments.text: When I load the hip_insert file, there are a number of spiky artifacts coming off one of the tabs.  Is this supposed to be like this?
comments.author: MrJ

comments.text: No. It should look just like the pictures.
comments.author: MrJ

comments.text:
I printed the hip joint's "insert" part vertically (not how it's shown; ugh; I try to
upload .stl files already oriented for printing) -- narrower box facing upwards, so the "locking tabs" are vertical, with the bump at the top.
comments.author: TimeFramed

comments.text: Hey, thanks for making this remix.  I was about to do this yesterday on my single extruder but I realize I couldn't position the hip joint so that it doesn't need supports.  The waist joint is good, however.  Can you possibly design the hip joint so it slides in like the waist joint?
comments.author: rikkilambo

comments.text:
The hip joint's insert part is supposed to print with support
(between the tabs, and underneath). Of course you remove the support
from the bottom, but you cannot remove the support between the tabs;
that's ok; there just needs to be a little flexibility of the tabs.
comments.author: rikkilambo

title: Very Shallow Terrain & Figure Storage Tray (3/4") Ikea Kallax and Expedit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
SURPRISE! Yet another tray for my series of Ikea Expedit or Kallax storage shelves/bookcases (13" x 13" x 3/4" deep). This one is quite shallow at 3/4" deep, designed with the intent to conserve vertical space among my miniature trays for all those low height terrain pieces and 10mm figures (as pictured). Designed for easy carrying and to hold modest amounts of weight. The provided template has a blank space that you might fill with other cutting patterns (or not) and is designed with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. You can customize them at your own leisure with labels and text as demonstrated in the pictures provided.

Terrain not included, you can find those bits under my other creations.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size, which fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

The pictured dust cover is also available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2208729

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: FeloniousPunk

description.text: In 1890, this telescope was already partially under construction, and it was planned to be the world's largest telescope. It was, in fact, the world's largest telescope from 1897 (when it was commissioned) to 1909, and it is still the world's largest refractor. The lenses started as glass disks cast by Mantois of Paris and were polished into 40-inch lenses by Alvan Clark and Sons in Cambridgeport, Massachusetts. Warner and Swasey of Cleveland built the mounting for the telescope and a 90-foot diameter dome to house it. They also constructed a 75-foot diameter movable floor that raises astronomers to the telescope eyepiece. This is necessary because the telescope pivots about the middle of the telescope tube: if one end points to a star low on the horizon, the other end (through which you want to look) will be far off the ground. So, the floor rises so that you can be hoisted up to the eyepiece.

title: HDMI cable support for DJI Phantom/Inspire

description.text:
DJI cable protector for Phantom and Inspire controllers.

HDMI and usb cables plugged into a DJI Phantom or Inspire controller can be easily damaged with even a small amount of pulling or twisting.

This mount is designed to slot into the rear metal handle of the DJI Phantom and Inspire controller to help support and protect cables and ports from accidental damage.

Since there are a variety of cables and adapters that people use, I designed this with a secondary customizable adapter tray that fits into the main mount. Ideally you want a snug fit for your cables in the adapter tray, if they don't quite fit or align, you may consider customizing your own adapter for your particular cables.

Important note: Be careful with using an adapter the first time, - if it doesn't quite fit or align your cables to the ports, you may do damage if you force it! Better to customize a new adapter tray. Scad file to follow once I clean it up a bit. ;)

Fly safe!

description.text: Owl with spinning head
Arduino code:

Servo myServo;
int pos=0;
int analogSensor=0; void setup(){
myServo.attach(9);
myServo.write(0);
Serial.begin(9600); }
void loop() {
pos=analogRead(analogSensor);
Serial.println(pos);
pos=map(pos,0,750,0,180);
myServo.write(pos); // tell servo to go to position in variable 'pos'
delay(15); // waits 15ms for the servo to reach the position }

title: Kossel Clear auto calibration probe deployment post

description.text: Simple post to deploy auto calibration probe. The post is a piece of 1/8" carbon fiber rod. Length of the rod is 50 ~ 60 mm. A 3 x 20mm bolt is threaded through the print bed near the edge and is used to retract the probe. The bolt is covered with some heat shrink tubing. See it in use here: http://youtu.be/fT3f_RupB9k

comments.text:
Thank you for designing this and publishing it. It was the second thing I built with my Kossel Clear!
I only needed to use half of it, and I attached it to one of the bolts on the MDF (I have the heated bed variant).
For the 1/8" rod, I used a 3mm drill bit, but a 1/8" drill bit would also have worked.
I modified the code for deploy_z_probe() and retract_z_probe() in Marlin_main.cpp to automatically deploy and retract the probe.
Works like a charm! :-)
comments.author: huntley

comments.text: I see there's another Kossel Clear in the Aloha State.  I found using deploy/retract_z_probe() in the firmware causes the head to move in an arc.  It took a few head crashes before I realized what was going on.  I hope mapping out the head moves was uneventful for you.
comments.author: huntley

comments.text: awesome work! could you share the gcode for the move?
comments.author: jayjayn

comments.text: I ended up writing the moves to deploy and retract the switch into the firmware.  So now, issuing a G29 makes the printer perform the whole routine.  You'll have to fine tune the gcode to your machine, but the gist of it is to move the head toward the arm, scoot under it and lift.  Run G29.  Move the head toward the stud on the bed, lower it then slide it sideways and up.  I didn't keep my actual code but this should be in the ballpark.  Try the moves manually a step at a time until it's dialed in.  And get ready to pull the plug in case it goes somewhere unexpected.
comments.author: jayjayn

comments.text: Where would I find this retractable probe design?
comments.author: zypher

comments.text: It's integral to Blue Eagle Lab's hotend design - you can get it here: http://www.blueeaglelabs.com/pages/open-source-fileshttp://www.blueeaglelabs.com/p...

title: Mount / Case for Sparkfun 20x4 serial LCD

description.text: I had an old Sparkfun 20x4 serial enabled LCD lying around and I decided to make it work for my Printrbot Simple. My version was older and has the serial backpack soldered to it. If you get a new one from Sparkfun, you don't need the box sticking out the back, as the serial circuit is built in. This is being driven by a custom script on my Raspberry Pi, which is running Repetier-Server. New LCD here: https://www.sparkfun.com/products/9568

description.text: The Mosaic Palette and Palette+ use a scroll wheel to measure the filament. This is connected to your extruder with a length of PTFE. This tube must not have sharp bends and should be relatively short. Large delta printers are a challenge with placing the scroll wheel. So I got the idea to mount the scroll wheel on a rotating base (find that here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2395627) to track the delta effector as it moves up/down and all around. I found that the best place to position the scroll wheel was 1/2 between the base and top of the delta. So I designed these brackets to mount a 10mm x 10mm extrusion as an auxiliary tower on which to mount the scroll wheel. The photo should be self explanatory (it is difficult photographing a 500mm tall delta printer like this in close quarters!)

title: MP GT2 X Carriage Dual Fan Mount

description.text:
I wanted to upgrade my V1 to a E3D V6 style hot end. After much researching I found 2 upgrades that I really liked, Select Mini GT2 Carriage for E3Dv6 Style Nozzle by USWaterRockets and E3D mount for MP Select Mini by aliimam. I like the concept of using a radial fan as they produce a large volume of air in a small package. Unfortunately this was designed for the original MP mount which I would be eliminating. So I came up with this design so if you are using the GT2 mount you can just swap out the GT2 Fan Shroud with this one.

Designed to work with or without the guard shield.

Hardware : M3 screws, 1-20mm & 1-35mm. 2-M3 nuts.

Fan used : DC 12V 0.15A 2 Pin Connector Cooling Blower Fan 50mmx15mm for Laptop Black

Printer:

MP Select Mini V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

25

Notes:

Supports are required, I used S3D, Support Type: Normal, Support Pillar Resolution: 6.00mm, Generated then add 16mm Support Pillar to the Nozzle leaving some of the exhaust port showing.
To remove support from the air tunnel, drill a small hole ¾ of the way thru the support. Compress the upper layers, I used a Philips screw driver. Using a 3” deck screw or similar, screw in about 1” wiggle and pull. The first few layers may need to be pulled out with needle nose plyers. After the top few layers are removed, compress again and reinsert screw, using plyers pull the remaining support out.

Preliminary testing at 60% fan speed have given excellent results.

comments.text: Hey! Thank you for the great design! I've printed it and have it mounted on my 3d printer. My only problem is I can't get the fan to turn on. There was one spot on the motherboard that said "FAN" so I plugged the fan in there but it's not running. Any ideas? What did you do to get power to the 2nd fan?
comments.author: brettwrightnow

comments.text:
Thank you for your comment. There is a know issue with some boards, see this article. https://www.mpselectmini.com/mainboard_cooling_fan
I spliced the new fan into the existing fan on my V1 & v2 with no issues. You can control the fan speeds after layer 1. I set layer 2 to 50% and layers 4 and on to 90%, works great. Hope this helps.
comments.author: brettwrightnow

comments.text: Ah! That's probably it! I thought that once it reached above 55 degrees, it would kick on. But it never did. Maybe there's some code or other modification to make for it to work.

comments.text: this should be in http://instructables.cominstructables.com ... great job
comments.author: Mando5

comments.text:
I used to do a lot of lost wax casting and played with this idea a few months ago.
My best formula was ~60% beeswax and 40% LDPE (or LLDPE) ... (linear) low density polyethylene from zip-lock plastic bags. Blend together in a low-temp hot pot. This mix could be extruded from a simple manual "clay extruder" (search amazon) when only slightly warmed above room temp, like 120F. The filament was pretty strong and flexible.. could be wrapped in a coil. Adjust proportions to change the flexibility and hardness.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
I also am a big lost wax casting advocate (former jeweler)
The ldpe i have heard being mixed with parafin for a carving wax mix.
actually also hdpe. not sure what the right balance would be, but ideally
a wider transition period and some flexibility and memory would be best.
this was why i had originally thought injection wax, as it does have the
memory and flexibility (which would be helpful in the filament feeding)
the transition period is sticking point, but i suspect you are on the right track.
plese do keep experimenting and keeping us posted!
I for one had all but abandoned the idea of direct print of a good investment
casting media.
(i actually am working on a semi- automated 3d pantograph for subtractive
work on waxes using ABS/pla models for originals to trace/reduce and carve
into wax.)
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text: I worked at an art foundry and did mostly large bronze stuff, but casting all kinds of materials has interested me since childhood.
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: I haven't tried it myself, but from what I understand, natural PLA works great as a substitute for wax in lost-wax casting.  Apparently it burns with very little residue.
comments.author: Terminus

comments.text:
I am guessing by the pictures, you are extruding what looks like injection wax to a 1.75 diameter
and then printing with a FDM printer.
if so, yes please give some specific information.
(which wax are you using, what is the parameters of the wire extruder?)
comments.author: cerberus333

comments.text: Agreed.  Would really like to read about some details on your process.
comments.author: Printed_Solid

comments.text: Some more information besides just a few pictures would be nice.

author: rj9791

print_settings.Notes:: EDIT: Printing the center piece for the second time round, I found out it does require the blessing of the 3D Print Gods :-P because if your bed isn't totally flat (mine is bent after hundreds of printing hours) things will get knocked over by the head's movement. If you run into that problem, check out pyramid-center-mod2 and pyramid-center-mod3, which are more sturdy thanks to some inbuilt support.

title: Modular Pyramid Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A set of pieces for building scalable pyramid (octahedral) networks using widely available wooden skewers (barbecue sticks).
Don't hesitate to resize the designs depending on available material, the files use 4mm holes for 3mm skewers (diameter) but this might vary according to printer precision. With 3.5mm skewers I used 4.5mm holes, so I resized the pieces by +1/8th (times 1.125).
Pieces required (depending on pyramid size):

  • level 1: 1 top and 4 angles
  • level 2: an extra 4 edges, 4 sides and 1 bottom
  • level 3: an extra 4 edges, 4 sides, 4 faces, 3 bottoms, and 1 center

Each extra n-th level will require an extra (n+1)^2 pieces, of type edge, side, face, bottom and center... Once you get the hang of it, you will be able to calculate the quantities.
I'm thinking of running a permanent contest of the biggest pyramid that was actually realised,so don't hesitate to send your photos (I'm stopping at level 3 as you can see from the photos). I'll be glad to hear from you !

Pieces don't need support, or a brim (if you have good adhesion), except for the center piece (which has tubes all round, by necessity).

New feature: triangular-based pyramids: these require the tri-corner and tri-edge pieces. I just tested it and it seems to work fine.

  • level 1: 4 tri-corner
  • level 2: an extra 6 tri-edge
  • level 3: an extra 6 tri-edge and 4 face (the regular kind)
  • level 4: an extra 6 tri-edge, 8 face and 1 center
    Actually it's the same kind of network, just rotated, so there's probably plenty of hybrids that are achievable from the same pieces. If you need one that isn't here, please let me know, it can be made in a minute !

Another new feature (on the triangle-based pyramid): little shelves that fit on the (horizontal) triangular cells, so that small objects can be arranged inside... makes an interesting shelf structure for small objects. Designed for 7cm sticks and 9mm nodes (scale factor 1.125). Don't hesitate to rescale them to your needs, should work anyway if sticks are long enough (at least a third of node distance must be exposed).

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Center piece does require support and brim, as opposed to the others.
Infill has little importance, because there is very little of it (you might make it with no infill, potentially).

EDIT: Printing the center piece for the second time round, I found out it does require the blessing of the 3D Print Gods :-P because if your bed isn't totally flat (mine is bent after hundreds of printing hours) things will get knocked over by the head's movement. If you run into that problem, check out pyramid-center-mod2 and pyramid-center-mod3, which are more sturdy thanks to some inbuilt support.

Some of the pieces I built required some cleaning of the tubes to be usable (this seems less likely if the pieces are printed one by one, and also my printer is a very cheap model). In that case I suggest using 3mm and 3.5mm drill heads, possibly heated with a lighter (it's a bit messy but it's fast and it works).
No glue is required, the Thing holds by itself due to the static forces that make up the triangles.
I cut down the sticks to 7cm segments (they're all the same size, due to a mathematical singularity), it might be difficult to assemble if they're shorter because you have to bend them a little bit.
Just use standard wooden skewers (barbecue sticks) and chop them apart (all the same length) using wire cutters (like the ones on most universal pincers). I did that with a pocket universal tool (Leatherman-like), you won't need any advanced tool.
I suggest building the Thing from the bottom up, the lower levels are hardest (sticks tend to snap out while you're trying to get their neighbours in). Be patient, it works eventually !
Designed with Blender and some knowledge of regular polyhedrons... There's really not much to it, I'm thinking of generalising the system using an OpenSCAD customisable script.

comments.author: wimdegroot

comments.text: One of the legs of the pyramid-face.stl is not touching the build plate in the first layer.
comments.author: wimdegroot

comments.text:
Yes, that's right.
I made the model with Blender and then had to rotate it to optimise for flatness.
This results in an angle that is probably less than 0.1 degrees, but sufficient for the slicer to react.
However, building support will produce a small bit of matter that's hard to remove because it's at the end of a closed pipe.
I would suggest not building support, and admitting there will be a small drop at that point. It should work anyway, as far as I know (you shouldn't have more trouble with that than with the upright pipes).
If this happens to be a real problem, tell me and I'll find a real solution (that might involves advanced trigonometrical calculation, and more rounding errors...).
If you give it a try, don't hesitate to let me know, thanks !
comments.author: wimdegroot

comments.text:
OK, I went into it and actually found something weird in the model.
Looks like I went into too many rotations, and rounding errors summed up to produce something bad.
I did it again from scratch and now it seems to work, over here at least.
I uploaded a new version, please tell me if it's okay for you too.
Thanks for your help !

description.text:
Custom webshooters for a spidey costume, only the bottom of the shooters and a cartridge, still working on the tops of the shooters, i will update when they get done... scale up to 10
The only part you may need to remake is the extender as it was modeled to fit my hand

Why have a console that plays defense when you can have one that is truly and utterly offensive? The Sword is the newest console that transforms and enriches (not really) your gaming experiences. Remember the Nvidia Shield? The one with a screen built into a controller and had super high-end graphics? Yeah, me either but this product is in direct competition to that.

Q: So really what is it?
A: Just a game clip really.

Q: Why did you make it?
A: Because I was bored.

Q: C'mon!
A: OK. I'm someone who enjoys repurposing old tech and hates seeing perfectly functional tech go to the landfill. I'm sure I'm not the only one out there with a extra phone (Samsung Galaxy Nexus in my case) and a old wired Xbox 360 controller so I thought I'd make something for all those people out there.

To complete this project you'll need the following items:

​A Phone of course
Wired Xbox 360 Controller (Will not work on Wireless version)
OTG Cable (Make sure your phone can support OTG BEFORE printing anything.)
The Sword Main Body
The Sword Bottom clip OR Bottom Clip (Wide)
The Sword Top Clip
The Sword Cable Wrap OR Cable Wrap (Hook)
M6 Scew and Nut (#6 32 x 1in) <----- Cheating. I know.
Optional - sticky weather stripping or felt to increase gripping of the phone.
Optional - Arc Browser. Not a free app but one of the best darn launchers out there focused on retro gaming.

Notes: If your phone has a rubber-ish case the normal bottom clip should be fine otherwise I recommend using the wider bottom clip. I would also suggest adding some "grippy" material to both the top and bottom clips. The clips with the added weight of the wire wraps should provide a good amount of force to hold the phone in place.

If there's enough interest in this project I may adjust the design for wireless 360 gamepads.

Constructive criticism is more than welcome and if you feel this project was worth it, please consider tipping no matter how small the contribution. Thank you and enjoy :)

Printer:

Monoprice 3D Mini Select 3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Yes

.13125

30%
Rhino 3D

Thank you so much for producing this clip, saved me from having to buy another $40 dollar controller (Since I'm temporarily broke atm).

author: Grynn

description.text: Front part of the standard Ruger 10/22 receiver

title: Hot wire tensioner for CNC hot wire cutter

description.text:
This is a tensioner for the wire so it can change length and still have the same tension. It uses an continuous rotating servo and an Arduino Pro Mini.
The hot wire is winded up on the servo spool then over the small ball bearing down to the guide ring and from there to the other side of the CNC hot wire cutter Z axis. It's position is vertikal so the wire makes an 90 degree bend at the guide ring.
The potentiometer is in the same range as the original potentiometer from the servo. It adjusts in the code anyway.
The code is just a simple servo movement with potentiometer, nothing more.

author: SeeCoopPrint

description.text:
This is a filament clip for all filament diameters up to 4mm and all spools. It doesn't rely on anything being of any particular size and you have 4 options to adjust tension (more if you get creative). It also doesn't require a precise printer and it will never need to be replaced with frequent or prolonged use once printed.  
It has been designed and tested on my 1.75mm filament but I sized it for larger than 3mm filament. It fits well within the side walls of my current filament roll at all 4 tensions (with the weakest tension still holding it steady). I made it to fit within a filament roll of about 3.5cm. It is possible I may need to shrink it for 3mm filament in a smaller roll, or I may need to make an accessory (which I have already thought of) for multi-pronged spool holders.  
Hopefully the design doesn't require modification, but if it doesn't work for you please provide feedback and I will adjust as necessary.

How I made it...
This was made in SketchUp after a thought I had today. I was amazed, and extremely happy when the first print worked as well as it did. How to use it...
Loosen your filament in the spool and put a strand of filament in one channel. Tighten the filament and leave about 5cm between the end of the filament and the clip then Insert the filament into the clip. See screenshots for more detail.

description.text: This is a bracket to adapt an Antech light (http://a.co/jfEcPOR) to a standard GoPro mount.

Printer Brand:

Tinkerine

Printer:

Ditto Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

80%

Notes:

The default mount that came with the light did not seem strong enough to resist a mountain bike ride, which is what I need it for.
I included a cutout for the cable to exit towards the front, but there is actually enough space for it to go directly to the back between the "legs", as shown on the pictures.

After printing, I had to trim a bit the bottom face for the stop to fit in the grove between the cooling fins. Also, the fit was extremely tight; the GoPro mount was really bent at first. After a few days under stress, it looks like the bracket extended a bit and now the fit is perfect.
The model I uploaded has a slightly larger inner diameter and slightly thinner stop, so that should provide an easier fit (although not tested).

print_settings.Notes:: I've just printed it in PLA. No special treatments. Make sure it doesn't stick too well to your bed because it's very flat.
