WallThickness = 1.2
BlockSize = [10,10,10]
FontDepth = 0.5

QX12-MAGA Seed Starter

Make Agriculture Green Again

This is a seed starter pack that seeks to take advantage of the biodegradable(?) nature of PLA. The very thin Seed Holders have slots for the roots to grow through, but the idea is that they will break down in the soil, so the gardener will not have to disrupt the seedling, and can just transfer the seedling into the ground where roots can spread and microorganisms can break down the PLA.

(NOTE: Do your own due-diligence here! Composting PLA requires higher temperatures than home composting, but that's for a quick break down of PLA. I have some PLA objects outside that have started deteriorating in 3 months. I'm counting on the breakdown of the starches by microorganisms to finish the job. Just try a 6-pack for a season before you go crazy! I'll post my results as they become available!)

That’s the theory, anyway! We’ll see how this goes. As of Today, July 28, 2017, I have just transferred the seedlings and cells into the ground. In 3 months I will inspect one of the units to see what kind of PLA breakdown has occurred. I hope that the cells will breakdown in a single 6 month growing season. I have these planted in a USDA 6A climate. If anybody has a willingness to make a six-pack and send me their observations I would appreciate it.

There’s a notch on the cell. If your cell doesn’t fit all the way down, try rotating it 90 degrees. Then go by the notch location to get all the other cells in without having to guess every time! Also, things didn’t go so well when I printed more than 1 cell at a time. Don’t know why. Weird missing spots in the print. But you can try.

The BASE UNIT holds six seedling cells, and has a “well” so that the plants can be root-fed. In this manner, you can flood the plants for 20 minutes, and then use a turkey-baster to draw out the excess water from the “well” to prevent over saturation. There are channels on the base floor to allow even distribution of water to all the cells. The top of the channels are at 45 degree angles, so NO SUPPORT is required to print these.

I made the base out of PLA, but I would like to try something more durable like ABS, because I’ve designed the bases to be reusable. Just print out more PLA seed cells for next season!

I created the Bodies in FUSION 360. I’ve exported the bodies as separate STEP files that you may use for manipulating in a CAD environment. Have fun, and MAGA, one Thingi at a time! I've also included my native Fusion 360 Archive files.

-This was sliced and coded using ReplicatorG employing 2 shells (3 total) using PLA.

  • FlashForge Creator Pro (Similar to Makerbot Replicator 2)
  • Heated Bed 45 Celsius
  • Blue Painters Tape on bed, no further treatment
  • Print Temperature 220 degrees Celsius
  • Use supports No rafts for PLA.
  • Feedrate 40 mm/s
  • Travel Feedrate 55
    (If anybody has more optimum feedrates, please share!)

REQUEST: Please help me improve my sharing! STEP files have proven reliable for me to transport file between different CAD platforms. If STEPs are a problem for you, please let me know what other common and relatively generic Cad format works better for you.

comments.text: There is a concern with all filaments when it comes to food contact given the lack of information on the chemicals used during the manufacturing process. Similar to not using pressure treated wood for you vegetable garden due to the chemicals used in that process.
comments.author: lgv2016

comments.text: PLA is food safe but, colored ones are not. Generally the paint used in PLA is not food grade. Another problem is that the extruder assembly might leak brass into the print. Even though brass is quite tough, so is PLA (specially so if your PLA is natural), it might scratch the surface and the bits of brass might end up in soil. I will not lose sleep over brass going into soil but paint is a real problem.

description.text: The necktie segments are fully articulated and should print well without supports. The segment hinges are completely contained and will only require bending the the hinge to snap loose any stuck plastic. The necktie is made up of 3 articulated segments, the knot and a retaining washer. The tie segments are connected together by applying a drop of epoxy or other adhesive and tapping the pins on the part into the holes of the adjacent part. The retaining washer is attached with a #6 x 1/2" flat head wood screw. The neck strap is fed through the channel in the knot and can be whatever material is available. It was designed for a 5/8" cloth strap with velcro attached at the ends.

title: Power Add battery bank phone holder

description.text:
My Nexus 6p's battery seems to not last long enough for my Netflix watching while in bed. Generally I will use my PowerAdd battery bank to combat this issue without being tethered to a wall, but it became a problem as I didn't want to hold the phone let alone the phone and the battery. This model when printed as a pair clips onto the battery to hold the phone.

It will likely work on other phone models as is a centimeter of clearance on the stand to account for my phone's case.

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a glass tensioner based on:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2260586

but the author never uploaded a separated SLT file, so whenever I wantd to print only one, I need to edit his STL and I took less time to create my own, in a parametric way, using Fusion 360, so you can edit it to meet your printer sizes.

Fusion 360 file: http://a360.co/2uHiHiD

you need to print

1x corner_a: the tensioner itself
3x corner_b: standard corners to hold the glass

materials:
2x Nut and Bolt, in order to tension the glass, check photos

optional:
I am adding also a spacer (corner_c), which will make some space for small bolts like mine and also provide a better surface (plastic/glass vs metal/glass)
please send me a comment if you have questions or requests

Update:
added replaced circle with a slot at the base (thanks for the idea! https://www.thingiverse.com/jcmunozac), please download the fusion 360 file in its latest version (v19 at this point)

Notes:

Recommended: use Brims, since they are really small parts and a tiny warp can mean easily 25% of the solid merged, then remove it with cutters
Make a bolt & nut less version, using some printed mechanism to generate the tension, stay tuned

description.text:
Parts cooler that is a front mount for the FT-5 with a titan aero installed (probably will work with any aero cooler).

This will work with the front cross bar in place, and only lose roughly 5mm of build surface in the y axis.. Of course it would work better with it removed and zero build surface lost.

remixed_from.author: CallJoe
remixed_from.title: ReMixed Wanhao Stepper Mounted Dial Indicator Mount

title: Maker Select V2 Dial Indicator Mount

description.text:
This is my first thing here, so go easy...

I really liked the ReMixed Wanhao Stepper Mounted Dial Indicator Mount by CallJoe but I didn't like its position on the side. I had already replaced my front-mount cooling fan with a new blower and the Cii cooler shroud and so the front of my carriage was clear (easier to see too). I used the stepper motor stl to get the hole spacing and mounting portion for the dial indicator and modified it to attach to the old fan mount with two 3mm screws and nuts.

You can use a 1/4" bolt to hold the indicator in place while you take the measurements around the bed and make adjustments (I began using a 1/4-20 machine screw and wing nut) but the fit on the indicator lug is tight enough that it will press in place and hold well enough to make your adjustments and then pull it off of the bracket (leaving the bracket in place) when you are ready to print. At the very least the dial fits tight enough and indexes against the face of the bracket such that just sliding the machine screw through the holes will hold the indicator very soundly without the need for a nut or wingnut.

comments.text: I like it!!! Going to print it tomorrow. I have replaced my stock blower as well and have been wanting to get a dial indicator set up on my machine.

description.text:
Magnetic modular zero strain spool holder. Works with the Creality CR-10 or on any metal surface. Will work with any size spool and is modular. Optionally, the straps can be rigidly connected to each other if magnets are not used turning it into a traditional spool holder of any custom size.

An advantage is that the feed can be slanted at any angle to match the feed angle of your extruder.

Required:
4 x cheapie 608 bearings
4 x neodymium magnets 10x20x5mm (optional)

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50-100%

Notes:

Designed in Fusion 360

Assembly

-Snap bearing into place (press fit)
-Insert magnets
-Snap together

Enjoy!

comments.text: These look good for use in the bottom of my dry box.  I've ordered some of the magnets from China at $1.55 for 8 pcs.  They are on a slow boat somewhere.  Got some sheet steel from Home Depot, and so far the plan is to cut a piece of the sheet out with snips and cover the bottom of my Ikea Salma dry box.  Right now all the filament rolls are on shafts, and it's a real production to swap any out.  I'm hoping this approach substantially simplifies that process.  I may end up thinning the layer between the magnet and the metal bed to gain as much force there as possible.  I don't want these to shift unintentionally.  Any suggestions there?
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: Hi Dave, yeah these work like a dream, one of the most useful things I've made. The magnetic holding force with the sized Neodymium magnets is substantial and will not move. You may even get away with placing the box on a metal surface or placing the sheet under the box and have enough holding force(providing your box is flat at the bottom)
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: Thanks for the offer, I will let you know if I need the file, but probably will be fine.  The Ikea Salma boxes have feet below their floor, so unlikely the 'under the box' tricks would work. I'm hoping I can find someone nearby with a sheet metal shear, to keep things looking classy.
comments.author: trentster

comments.text: I received the magnets and they fit and work perfectly.  They securely hold the assembly in place but I wanted to get all I could from the magnets, so I thinned down the base to have only two layers between the magnet and the plate.  I've cut down some sheet metal to fit my two Ikea "Salma" dry boxes, and am busily printing 7 more sets of holders.  I will post once it's completed to show how it turned out.
comments.author: davebpix

comments.text: Hi Dave, glad you got the magnets and can't wait to see how it all turned out. You should not need to glue the two halves together the bearings are a push fit(if you have your print tolerances nailed down) and will securely hold the two together. You can of course glue, but this makes it a pain to replace a bearing should you ever need to do so. If you are dead set on gluing, then plain old Generic Loctite superglue works great for PLA. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HvIu98A9GA8&t=5s

author: barneyj

description.text:
Realizado con Tinkercad. Edítalo online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0oBj5t3CPiZ

Diseño 3D del robot realizado durante el curso gratuito de la UPV (curso MOOP):

Diseña, fabrica y programa tu propio robot.

Es un remix del modelo del curso: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2034628
Modificaciones:

Ruedas tractoras delante, diseñadas nuevas y movidas por dos Servo Motores de rotación contínua FS90R.
Rueda loca trasera, diseñada nueva.
Diseño de Bender, personage de Futurama. Sensor ultrasónico de distancia, Matriz LED 8x8, zumbador pasivo, modulo de comunicación bluetooth, Sensor infra-rojo (modulo seguilíneas), plancha de madera 150 x 150 x 3 mm.
Control por Arduino Nano v3.0, montado en placa expansora ARD-NANO-B.
Las pinzas fueran hechas y montadas en el robot, pero no fue posible exportar su dibujo hecho en Tinkercad (.str) para cargar en Thingiverse. Son movidas por dos Servos Motores SG92R de posición. Materiales: dos piezas de cables eletricos flexibles (8 mm diametro por 12 cm de largo), una corcha, y pintura metálica.

¡Gracias por el curso!

Para más información:

Curso MOOC EdX: https://www.edx.org/course/disena-fabrica-y-programa-tu-propio-upvalenciax-dyor101x

Portal de formación robot DYOR: http://dyor.roboticafacil.es

Blog robótica de la UPV: http://robotica.webs.upv.es

Twitter (@roboticaUPV): https://twitter.com/roboticaUPV

Facebook (robótica UPV): https://www.facebook.com/roboticaUPV
NGSS

Required skills Not much, Tinkercad software easy to use, but still limited when it comes to more complex 3D drawings since it get more and more difficult to place parts in right position, axis interpreting becomes confusing.

Materials and drawing Better to order materials as soon as possible so that they will be available to take dimensions and start drawing, it will take time to fit all in a 150 x 150 mm area, with parts in hand is possible to check positioning against area available.

Materials Just follow the provided list, similar parts are not that easy to find since some are not available, difficult to find specifications for most of items to compare and try to match with any other similar available in the market.
• Tinkercad Software

Listado de materiales
  • Arduino Nano v3.0 (compatible) con cable USB
  • Placa Expansion I/O para Arduino Nano
  • 2 servos FS90R
  • Ruedas de 60mm para servos FS90R
  • 1 rueda loca
  • Módulo Bluetooth SPP-C (compatible HC-06)
  • Módulo seguilíneas Infrarojo S-95
  • Sensor ultrasonido HC-SR04
  • 20 cables DuPont hembra-hembra 20cm
  • Módulo de matriz LED 8×8 max7219
  • Módulo zumbador de sonido KY-006
  • 2 servos SG92R (compatible con SG90).
  • Dos piezas de cables eléctricos 8 mm x 120 mm, una cocha, pinturas metalica y oscura.
  • Alimentador (powerbank) USB de 2000mAh

Made for the Wombot but can fit any 3030 rail.
Adding Filament runout sensor very easy on 2.0.0 Marlin.
Runs off D4 in Servo's section of MKS Gen board.
Then by undefine FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR in Configuration.h
Then undefine: ADVANCED_PAUSE_FEATURE in configuration adv.h
Buy the Crash Collision Sensor Detection Module /w Switch for Arduino Smart Robot 1pc from Ebay or Aliexpress.
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/Crash-Collision-Sensor-Detection-Module-w-Switch-for-Arduino-Smart-Robot-/131655795814

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-Impact-Switch-Collision-Switch-Sensor-Module-With-Dupont-Line/32294958229.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.5chV7F
Not my making, but I am making it available to print.

title: Simple Clone Arduino Pro Mini Mount

description.text:
A mount for the cheap Arduino Pro Mini clone found all over ebay, the style with the pins around every edge. Loosely based on a number of other similar designed I've see.

I made this to attach to my mGiraffe printer, which is made of 24x24 aluminum extrusions and M4 screws. The holes on this mount are 4.2mm and the socket cap head screws that mount it are what also hold the Pro Mini in, which slides from either end. I will eventually make a 3mm version for my other printer.

The clones I made this for, I found that they are slightly wider than the "more accurate" clones, ~18.7mm vs ~18.3mm. The narrow board may fit fine but might not be very secure.

Per my usual with everything I've designed from scratch, the Fusion 360 file is included. Have fun adjusting this to your needs. :D

Printer:

mGiraffe

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

You'll want it to be stiff. I used 3 perimeters.
If you use right angle pin headers for the ISP pins, like I did, screw in that side of the mount first then slide the board in and attach the other end to secure both.

author: Kadah

title: Bit Holder for the Drill Master Cordless Screw Driver

description.text:
My favorite new tool acquisition is a cheap Harbor Freight special, cordless screw driver made by Drill Master. I've used it constantly since getting it and my only two complaints are how hard it is to remove the bits, which I suppose is both feature a swell as bug, and how easy it is to loose the bits when they're not in use.

This little design should help with the later of the two.

Its designed to be tied to the wrist strap of the screwdriver and contains three magnets (Item #67488 also found at Harbor Freight) which holds the bits securely.)

The magnets and the two printed parts are held together with a little super glue and the whole thing is looped onto the wrist strap with a bit of bit wire.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.175

Infill:

20

author: JaboDLJ

title: Body Post Screw Knob set Design 2

description.text:
I designed these knobs as a cosmetic upgrade to replace the original ones that I have
design a few months ago due to its size and it appears kind of bulky but it is reliable
and will remain as an option. The purpose of this new design is to make the knobs a
bit smaller at a reasonable size and also make it more unique. And also help make it
easier to identify the RC vehicle from everyone else's if that rc vehicle is with its
owner at the track. And because I can do so. If you wish to download these files you
will need about four screws for the base they need to be 3x30mm And the photos should
show you how to install the 3D printed body mounts.

As for the knobs themselves you will need 4 stop nuts they need to be 3mm also
Depending upon your 3D printer and how you print the parts themselves you will need
a dremel power tool with a special bit as you see in the photos and a exacto knife
And also depending upon your vision you will need a loupe that Jewelers & watchmakers
use to magnify your vision so you can see what you're doing As you clean up the area
where the stock not will go. And also you will need four Traxxas Foam Body Washers part
no.4915 or something similar to this to put on the body of the RC vehicle to provide
some friction for the knobs themselves so they would not damage the body of the
RC vehicle. After that the photos should give you an idea how to assemble it I apologize
for the blur photos but you should get the idea how to install it. After that the
photos should give you an idea of the end product so enjoy this upgrade.

title: Armello Die
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
My take on a physical version of the die used in the digital board game, Armello. Had a cockamamey idea of converting the game to a physical version at some point, but eventually decided not to go through with it. Still, these turned out beautifully and thought I should share them.

For those familiar with the game (and why else would you be looking at this otherwise), these were modeled after a mix of the die templates "Pride's Destiny" & "Traitor's Gift".

To make these, print out each die face separately, and simply adhere them to the cube using plastic cement or some other acetone based glue. I printed through 3dHubs, so I don't have all the print settings, but I've included what I can. They are designed to not require supports.

These would likely work out better printing them with a dual extruder, but I was playing the hand I was dealt and am honestly still very unfamiliar with such things.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 Microns

Notes:

0.2mm Nozzle
After (painfully) removing them from their rafts, each face required quite a lot of preening and filing to smooth their backs. Also needed a fair amount of filing to make up for the warping.

author: Wyndrarch

description.text:
Parametric TV Mount - Version 3

Original Concept: Thingiverse Thing #2457239 (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2457239)
Designer: mfuse

Create a parametric TV Mount based on mfuse's design with pseudocode and code comments designed to explain the details of building this model in OpenSCAD.

OpenSCAD

3D Model created using OpenSCAD version 2016.10.05 with the Customizer enabled.

Version History

7/29/17 Version 1

  • Simple code
  • Pseudocode and verbose descriptive comments

7/29/17 Version 2

  • Slightly more complex code
  • Pseudocode and verbose descriptive comments

7/30/17 Version 3

  • Removed pseudocode
  • Add the following functionality:
    -- Add a "Nut" option to the cutouts
    -- Add a "None" option to the cutouts
    -- Ability to change the side of the model the Countersink or Nut cutout is on
    -- Cutout options are now: Countersink, Nut or None

Main Body
  • Center a square on the origin and rotate it 45 degrees on the Z axis. This is the "Diamond Plate".
  • Center a rectangle on the origin. This is one of the two rectangles that will make up the "arms" of the adapter.
  • Center a second, identical rectangle on the origin and rotate it 90 degrees on the Z axis so it is perpendicular to the first rectangle. This is the second of the two rectangles that will make up the "arms" of the adapter.
  • Place a circle centered on each end of both rectangles. This will round off the end of all four "arms".
  • Extrude the existing 2d model on the Z axis (give it height) creating a 3d model.
Screw Holes Cutouts Model
  • Punch Out and Countersink* the 4 holes that make up the TV mount side of the adapter.

  • Punch Out and Countersink* the 4 holes that make up the wall mount side of the adapter.

  • Use the Screw Holes Cutout Model to place the proper holes in the Main Body.
*Punch Out and Countersink
  • Create a cylinder slightly larger than the outside diameter of the thread of the intended screw.
  • Create a cone where the larger diameter is the outside diameter of the intended screw and the smaller diameter is the same as the cylinder diameter. These diameters are also slightly increased for tolerance. Raise the cone to the top of the cylinder on the Z axis.

• Code is formatted to utilize Thingiverse's Customizer and OpenSCAD's Customizer Plugin.
  • v1 of the model is available as a text file. Download the text file and rename it "TV Wall Adapter - Parametric v1.scad" then open it with OpenSCAD.
  • v2 of the model is available as a text file. Download the text file and rename it "TV Wall Adapter - Parametric v2.scad" then open it with OpenSCAD.
  • The pseudocode above is from v2. It has been left for those who are learning OpenSCAD to use as a learning tool. The user can compare the pseudocode to the v2 code.
  • Pseudocode is included in v1 and v2 text files.

Warning

This model was designed as a programming exercise. I strongly advise against using this model with most plastics to mount a television or monitor. Should you attempt to use this model with most 3D printed plastics there is a large probability that the mount will fail and damage/destroy your monitor and possibly injure anyone in the area at the time.

Disclaimer

The author is in no way responsible for damages or injury resulting from printing and/or using this model. As previously stated it was the result of a programming exercise and not intended for use with 3D printed materials.

This is a circular saw guide for cutting 3/4" EMT conduit. A hose clamp secures the guide to the conduit, and the large flat shoulder gives you something to run the saw along. This version cuts 90-degrees to the length of the conduit, and should help you make a straight cut more easily. You can also use the miter setting on your saw, and since it should tilt the blade away from the short edge, that should not interfere with the guide.

This part is designed such that you line up the end of the flat section to your cut mark (you'll need to account for the width of the blade). These particular dimensions come from my Ridgid brushless circular saw, so your edge-to-blade distance may be different, and you might need to trim down the flat part. Feel free to comment any dimensional changes you might need, it won't take long for me to make those changes and add the file here for you.

Since this part has a radially asymmetrical profile, I decided not to try to do a revolve on this part. Instead, I extruded the round part of the body as a cylinder and extrude cut a ring out of the middle to give the hose clamp somewhere to sit. I then extruded the entire funky-D shaped section to the size of the vertical shoulder, and extrude cut in the horizontal section. All of the major geometry was done in the sketch itself before extrusion to limit the number of extrusions I had to perform. This part was made in SolidWorks.

It's easiest to print this standing upright on the round end, that way you get a decently flat section on top.

print_settings.Notes:: If you have troubles with holes on vertical faces, you may want supports (that don't touch bed). Otherwise no supports are necessary.

description.text:
This is a REMIX of my previous mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2347578). This one raises the camera 60mm higher so as not to catch the gantry supports in the image when on lower layers. This works with the original camera clamp from version 1, so if you already printed the first version, you'll only need to print the bracket from this version.

This is a quick and dirty Logitech C270 camera mount that I made for my Tevo Tarantula that is running on OctoPrint. I wanted something that allowed me to pose the camera, but was too lazy to design a ball/socket setup. I feel this will hold better in the long run anyway. It mounts on the left Z plate (original Tevo acrylic) and uses the two screws that hold the toothless pulleys. I was able to get it to fit with the existing screws. You also need a M4 x 10mm (or thereabouts) to assemble the camera bracket to the mount. An M3 x 16 or longer is needed to attach the camera to the bracket.

It may work with other models that have a similar camera housing. The hinge on this Logitech camera is 6mm wide and fits a 3mm pin (if that helps)

You will need to remove the existing clamp from the Logitech camera so that all you have left is the lens housing.

Once it's on, you can adjust the pan and tilt and tighten it down into place. You may also want to focus the camera (requires a little hacking). You can see how to do it here - https://tamarintech.com/article/ciclop_scanner_focus_fix

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm Layer Height

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Adjust layer height and infill to taste. The camera isn't that heavy, so it doesn't need to be super strong. And since I have it on the side of the Z rail that currently doesn't have a lead screw, I wanted it light weight.

If you have troubles with holes on vertical faces, you may want supports (that don't touch bed). Otherwise no supports are necessary.

Mounting

I just removed the two screws from the toothless pulleys on the acrylic and installed the cameramount_tall.stl under those. It's not rocket science :D

Remove the screw that holds the camera housing to the existing clamp. You may have to dig out the two little stick on rubber plugs. Fit the printed clamp (cameraclamp.stl) in it's place and assemble to the mount.

The wire for the camera is running in the bottom channel of the Z extrusion and out to the right side where my Pi is (next to the MKS), and I used the handy plastic extrusion caps that came with the Tevo to hold it in place. Worked like a charm!

You may want to focus your camera once it's set - https://tamarintech.com/article/ciclop_scanner_focus_fix

title: Raspberry Pi Star Guider with Offset Adjustment Platform
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In short

Offset adjustment platform for Raspberry Pi auto guiding system.

Overview

This is an integrated solution where the RPi board and the guide scope are being mounted onto the telescope. The goal is to allow fine offset adjustment of the guide scope, and to allow wireless, computer-less auto guiding.

Offset Adjustment

The platform includes a azimuth adjustment mechanism through a worm gear - spur gear set, and a altitude adjustment (tilt adjustment) through a curved sliding rail. This solution is more explicit and easy to control compare with the 2-pivot guide scope holder system.

Auto Guide

This system utilizes Raspberry Pi 3 and Raspberry Pi Camera (support both v1.3 and v2.1) as the auto guiding infrastructure. You can install your favorite OS (Ubuntu Mate, Raspbian, etc.), your favorite guiding software (OpenPHD, lin_guider, etc.) and any guide scope with a C/CS mount upon your focal length needs.

My own solution tested on Ubuntu Mate with OpenPHD 2.6 installed. Using INDI to control my Takahashi EM-11 via bluetooth-serial adapter (or SkyFi) and remote control the RPi using the WLAN built-in on the RPi 3 board, I can implement a complete wireless guiding solution. (A battery hang on the case can be used as the power supply!)

Depends on what guiding software and guide scope you are using, the result may be vary. In my experience, using a f=75mm f/2.8 CCTV lens with OpenPHD is not possible to spot any star on the night sky. This could be due to lack of exposure control of RPi-V4L2. Either switching to other guiding software (python based) or using a better scope can perform better. Though both the v1.3 or v2.1 RPi camera should have high enough resolution in cooperate with f=100-200mm guide scope. I can get some good result using a f=100mm f/2 scope to guide my Tak. FSQ-85.

Instruction

This stuff includes six 3D print parts, one RPi 3 board and RPi camera, a metal C/CS mount, many little screws and a set of gear. You can also find a printed version of C mount here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2728134.

Bill of material

3D Printed parts

  • Pi Box Base (to hold the RPi board and fix on the slider)
  • Pi Box Cover
  • Pi Camera Holder (with a metal C/CS mount fixed on it)
  • Altitude Adjust Slider
  • Azimuth Adjust Rotator
  • Azimuth Adjust Base

Other parts

  • Raspberry Pi 3, with SD card loaded
  • Raspberry Pi Camera v1.3 or v2.1, with stock lens removed, cable attached
  • Metal C/CS mount (I removed it from a cheap IP Cam, mounting hole spacing is 28mm. You may need to remix the holder to suit your case)
  • 1.7x8mm self-tapping screw for plastic x 16 (for joining the Pi Box cover, Pi Box base and slider, and holding the RPi Cam and C/CS mount on the holder)
  • 2x6mm self-tapping screw for plastic x 4 (for fixing the RPi board)
  • M3x15 screw and nuts x 7 (for fixing the RPi Cam holder on the Pi Box, and as the locking screw of both altitude and azimuth axis)
  • M4x12 screw with handle (for locking screw of the altitude slider)
  • [optional] M0.5x8 worm gear and M0.5x29 teeth spur gear (for azimuth fine tune)
  • [optional] a 2mm metal rod with handle to turn the worm gear (I use a micro screw driver for this)
  • [optional] 1.4x5mm self-tapping screw for plastic (for fixing the spur gear onto the base)

Tools

  • Screw drivers for small screws
  • 3.2mm drill (to bore holes for M3 screw)
  • [optional] M3 tap
  • [optional] M4 tap
  • [optional] 1/4" tap

Some parts may be missed in the material list above, please refer to my photos and the instruction below.

Assembling

Instruction to assemble the system is quite straight forward. Please refer to my photos for hints.

  1. Fix the C/CS mount onto the RPi Camera holder using 4 1.7mm screw
  2. Fix the RPi Camera onto the RPi Camera holder using 4 1.7mm screw
  3. Fix the RPi Box Base onto the Slider using 4 1.7mm screw
  4. Fix the RPi Camera assembly onto the RPi Box Base using 4 M3x15 screw and nut
  5. Fix the RPi 3 board onto the RPi Box Base using 4 2mm screw
  6. Cover the RPi Box Cover to the Base using 4 1.7mm screw
  7. Load the slider with M4 handle screw and M3 locking screw
  8. Insert 2 nuts on the bottom of the Azimuth Rotator
  9. Load 2 M3 locking screw on the bottom of the Azimuth Rotator
  10. Fix the spur gear onto the Azimuth Base using 1.4mm screw (you may need to drill some holes on the spur gear)
  11. Drop the worm gear into the slot on the bottom of the Azimuth Rotator
  12. Puncture the 2mm metal rod through the worm gear and the Azimuth Rotator
  13. Tap the center hole of the Azimuth Base with your favorite size (1/4" will suit most case)
  14. Place the Azimuth Base into the Rotator
  15. Finish

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

RepRap Kossel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50

Notes:

Printing all parts in ABS is recommended since you may need to machine them during assembly. Except the Azimuth Base I printed in PETG to improve durable and strength of the 1/4" thread.

I hate cables.

When using equatorial mount you need to connect many cables to complete your systems. It is very annoying when cables swings and affect the scope.

In this solution, I'm trying to reduce cables that hang on the scope to zero. Since I use common camera as the imaging device (Canon EOS 6D or M), the only cables that hang on the scope goes to the auto guide system. With Raspberry Pi 3, which have built-in Wi-Fi, Bluetooth and camera module, I can complete the guiding system solely on the scope wireless-ly.

author: Kylellrc

description.text:
I modified this one: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:672195

I made it taller so that I could add slots for roads, made the magnet holes pass all the way through the edges, made the magnet holes a little wider, added a hole in the center to reduce the weight a little.

Add the magnets

I placed 4 2mm diameter x 1mm thick neodymium magnets into each hole in the side and used a little super glue on each side to minimize the distance between the magnets and maximize the strength of the connection.

You could use fewer than 4 magnets per hole, but with 4, it can hold the weight of one other hex. I'm not sure if that is true with fewer.

The magnets I used could be found here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B072KRP66C/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o05_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Finish

I am currently playing around with other finishing techniques, including using XTC-3D, and acrylic matte varnish.

a simple spoke protector to mount on the bike frame by zip ties. print with some flexible material like ABS. Just fits on the print bed of an prusa 3i mk2.

I use it to keep bags that hang down on the side of the rear wheel away from the spokes.

In constant use since ~1 Month / ~500km. Tested up to 50km/h ;)

Broke after ~1000km of use. Better print it z-scaled 2x (so it is stronger). Since this re-print used for ~1500km without problem.

This holds a cheapie harbor freight dial gauge on the MakerBot Thing-O-Matic Z platform to aid in leveling.  Using this I was able to square the platform within 0.025 mm (0.001") - which is close enough for me.

1) Use Multiply Print 2
2) slide onto dial gauge with the flat sides down. Lower Z until it just touches and zero it to the lowest corner of the platform.
3) Mount on Z and jog/adjust platform until all 4 corners are square with the print head.

I will be printing this in the next couple of days. I will either post pics because it worked or I will delete this thing because it sucks... We shall see...

Update: I will post pictures of the finished board and report on its performance this week ( ~Aug 19)

I've been wanting to upgrade my longboard for a while so here it is. The goal of this project was to make a well ventilated, splash-proof electric longboard (not necessarily water-proof) capable of speeds 25+ mph and distances of 30+ miles. I still need to test it, but I am confident that my current design meets those standards.

The board I'm upgrading is The Fury from White Wave Longboards.
(http://www.whitewavelongboards.com/product/the-fury/)

The board is made of plastic and has thick support struts running down its length. My battery case was made to fit around those supports (after I carved the central supports down a little), so it may need to be modified in order to attach to other boards. I expect most of my future revisions on this Thing to be for modifications to the battery and esc cases.

The battery case holds 6 2s batteries.

The motor mount should work on most trucks. I have 180 mm trucks which have a base diameter of 20mm. Additionally, my trucks have 2 ribs on each side separated by 90 degrees and symmetric about the vertical axis. I have designed spaces into the truckAttachment and oppositeTruckAttachment files to accommodate this. If this won't work for your trucks, then I suggest playing with the parameters in the fusion 360 file. (Model User Workspace -> Modify --> Change Parameters)

In order to provide cooling to components while sealing them in against water, I've implemented 1/4" pneumatic tubing which starts at the "air mouths" (I don't know what to call them but they remind me of a rocketship), weaves between the batteries and attaches to the outside of the motorHolder. The front "air mouths" take in onrushing air as the board is moving. The 3d file doesn't show the motor, power switch, esc, bec, receiver, trucks, deck, wires or pneumatic tubing. Only those parts which need to be printed are included.

For a complete list of all the parts you need visit:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Cvg0MT1IT4_uRK75YSzm8nxsiFxqcZR9VikGt5nNFHw/edit?usp=sharing

If you have any questions or design suggestions, hit me up in the comment section.

title: End Plugs stock stand rollers for 1" (1.06) ID pipe

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/iEVeZXeHmcL

This is to take a cheap lumber stand and add rollers to it. I used 1.5" PVC pipe, but needed a way to keep it on the pipe. Viola! Tinkercad to the rescue. Printed like a dream, supports a tad bit hard to remove but only a 5 minute job. I used PLA but ABS would likely last longer.
It requires a screw for each plug, 10/32 x 1" and a washer and nut. Put the screw on the beveled side of the plug (bottom) and tighten the nut once the plug is inserted in the pipe with the PVC pipe on.

NOTE: I printed this 180° upside down to minimize supports. You can print as is or flip.

Printer:

da vinci mini

Rafts:

No

No

.2

Infill:

90%

guage mounting bracket

author: damianarenos

print_settings.Notes:: So this is all new to me, and I can't figure out how to change this easily in Fusion, so you will have to rotate the .stl along the x-axis before slicing it.

description.text:
This is an insert for the card game "Space Race" by Jan Soukal and Marek Loskot, that was originally released thru Kickstarter.

The original box insert that came with the game was actually designed to be modified to allow for sleeved cards, but it wasn't really a perfect fit, so I decided to make an insert for my first attempt at designing anything in 3D.

The result is a great fit for the box and accommodates sleeved cards (in my case - single Dragon Shields). The rocket storage space might not be the most spectacular, but i works.

Enjoy.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

So this is all new to me, and I can't figure out how to change this easily in Fusion, so you will have to rotate the .stl along the x-axis before slicing it.

So this was my first attempt at Fusion 360, or any 3d-design software for that matter. The design is obviously not terribly complex, but the mess I made of it before I finally got it to print is... Well lets call it a learning experience. :)

If for some reason you want a copy of the .step file let me know.

Cheers.

remixed_from.title: Armattan Chameleon Session Mount (hidden 4s Balance Plug holder)

title: RunCam3 Protective Cover with Chameleon mount

description.text:
Just added the Chameleon mount from "Armattan Chameleon Session Mount (hidden 4s Balance Plug holder)"
Ok, by just adding, I mean I've shortened the mount a few millimeters, so it will be harder to fit the carbon plate of the Chameleon. (the center of the plate is narrower, so there can be a little play still)

Also, a lot of thanks for the original Runcam3 mount design for glef:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2245865

only "downside": I could only fit the camera from behind, after putting the mount on the frame, it's a bit difficult to put the camera in (but I could do it).

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

26%

Notes:

I can print TPU real slow, 10mm/s for almost everything, 45mm/s travel.

TPU stringing

I don't use retraction for TPU, so there's stringing everywhere.
Just need to remove them, and you are good to go.

Meshmixer

Cut the mount from the session mount, narrowed it a bit, aligned it to the Runcam3 mount, and combined.

title: Rotary Rotor Volume Knob For Mazda RX8 Radio (MK3)

description.text:
This is my design of Rotary Rotor Volume Knob for the 2004 Mazda RX8.

Cura settings:
0.12mm layer (for high details prints)
0.8mm shell all round
printed speed: 22mm/s
infill: 30%
print temperature: 194'C

MK1 (Available)
First Release: 29/07/2017
Update: (Renamed as MK1) 22/02/2018

MK2 (Available)
First Release: 22/02/2018
Better shapes and inner gear

MK3 - (Available)
First Release: 23/03/2018
Redesign on MK2, more aggressive look and center gears.

MK4 - (WIP)
First Release: TBC
Center Gear move to correct position, also now it has been separated body, allowed user print in different colour.

MK5 (Non-Release Version)
